results.title: Touchez Pas Au Grisbi = Don't Touch the Loot
results.creator_credit: Jacques Becker, Leon Carre and Robert Dorfmann
results.brief_description:
Max and Riton have just executed a mighty heist and hidden the loot (grisbi) while things cool down. The heist was Max’s last coup before retirement. But Riton can’t help talking to his girlfriend, Josy. Josy is the talkative kind and passes the information to Angelo, a drug dealer. Angelo kidnaps Riton in order to make him reveal the location of the loot. Max must set aside his dreams of cosy retirement and respectability to retrieve his friend and the loot from Angelo’s grasp. It’s a kind of an older guys/young chicks picture with a pair of middle-aged men (Jean Gabin, Rene Darcy) dining at the same Montmartre cafe every night and heading for a nightclub where their girlfriends (Dora Doll, Jeanne Moreau) dance in the chorus. Gabin has reached the age where he’d like to have called it a night lots earlier if he didn’t have an image to maintain, but Darcy still likes to play around. Gabin’s girl (Doll) is an uncomplicated blond—the actress’ name fits the character she’s playing to perfection—but Moreau, not surprisingly, is not just another cutie with bangs and a ponytail. She’s got an eye on the main chance, and Darcy’s pillow talk has netted her the prize information that Gabin is sitting on a fortune in stolen gold bricks. When Gabin’s erstwhile comrade (Lino Ventura) hears this news, the plot of the film, adapted from an Albert Simonin serie noire novel, kicks in. What concerns Becker is that eternal theme, the question of honor among thieves. Gabin is suddenly thrust into a dangerous, volatile predicament, but his loyalty to the foolish Darcy never flags. ‘Grisbi’ is loaded with night-life atmosphere, and it offers the unique opportunity to see together France’s greatest screen icon, Gabin, the virile man of the people, with Moreau and Ventura, who were to become icons themselves. Indeed, Ventura (in his screen debut), whom Becker discovered in a wrestling ring, would eventually succeed Gabin as France’s definitive, world-weary tough guy. There are a couple of moments when Moreau, who would become the grande dame of the French cinema, has an uncanny Brigitte Bardot look, but already she projected a hauteur to be reckoned with.” Reference: Kevin Thomas. ‘Cinema dangereuse’. Hollywood Online, 18/6/98. Online. http://www.hollywood.com/news/topstories/06-18-98/html/1-3.html Further reference: Cinematheque Ontario: programme Fall 1999. http://www.bell.ca/filmfest/cinematheque/films/grisbi.htm

Credits: Producers, Robert Dorfmann, Leon Carre ; director, Jacques Becker ; writers, Albert Simonin, Jacques becker, Maurice Griffe ; photography, Pierre Montazel ; music, Jean Wiener ; editor, Marguerite Renoir.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Jeanne Moreau, Lino Ventura, Paul Frankeur, Daniel Cauchy, Rene Dary, Dora Doll, Marilyn Bufferd, Michel Jourdan.

results.title: Magic lantern set effects slide (Les jouers de cartes - the card players)
results.brief_description: Hand painted magic lantern set effects slipping slide in wooden frame [Les Jouers de Cartes - the Card Players]. By sliding the effects slide, two card players’ heads turn in to a chicken (left) and a dog (right).
results.title_for_label: Magic lantern set effects slide (Les jouers de cartes - the card players)

results.title: Man and Donkey lever magic lantern slide
results.brief_description: Magic lantern set effects slide with wooden frame. The coloured slide shows a portrait of a man wearing a hat in a circular slide. An adjustable handle allows the viewer to move a beard.
results.description: Magic lantern set effects slide with wooden frame. The coloured slide shows a portrait of a man wearing a hat in a circular slide. An adjustable handle allows the viewer to move a beard.

results.title: Magic lantern set effects slide (Blind man's bluff)
results.brief_description: Wooden magic lantern set effects slide with lever. When lever is moved upwards and downwards, a boy brushes glue on to a man’s back. Another boy is ready to attach a poster to the back.

results.title: Magic lantern three-panel slipping slide (Flower Bloom)
results.brief_description: Magic lantern set effects slide with wooden frame. The coloured slide shows a flower bud blooming. Two adjustable sliding pieces of glass - slide left and right to show the flower blooming. Set against a black background. Made by W.F. Archer, Liverpool, 43 Lord St and 63 South Castle St. ‘49’ and ‘R’ written in pencil on wooden frame.
results.description: Magic lantern set effects slide with wooden frame. The coloured slide shows a flower bud blooming. results.title: Magic lantern slipping slide (Le nez d'arlequin - the harlequin's nose)
results.brief_description: Hand painted magic lantern slipping slide ‘Le Nez d’Arlequin’ -‘ The Harlequin’s Nose’ or ‘Punch with Long Nose’ with wooden frame. Manufactured by E.Mazo, Paris. By moving the slipping slide, a harlequin’s nose grows longer and three small children appear on the tip. The words ‘Punch’s Long Nose’ is etched vertically in to the glass plate.
results.title_for_label: Magic lantern slipping slide (Le nez d’arlequin - the harlequin’s nose)

results.title: Magic lantern slipping slide (Knight and Princess)
results.brief_description: Magic lantern set effects slide with dark wooden frame. By sliding the effects slide, a a princess pushes a knight from her window or cuts his climbing rope, resulting in his fall Set against a black background.

results.title: Magic lantern slipping slide [Boy / Girl]

results.title: House in summer magic lantern slide
results.brief_description: Magic lantern slide with wooden frame. The coloured slide shows a English style house and gardens. Several pencil marking on the wood. On the underside, ‘57’ has been written in a thick white ink.
